title: 2020 Bentley Flying Spur review: nowhere near as special as it should be
text:
It sounds as exciting as soup; the saloon version of anything isn’t usually something to stir the blood – although you might have to make an exception in this instance.

Bentley introduced the Flying Spur name in 1959. It was an elegant saloon based on John Blatchley’s R-Type Continental coupé and named after the family crest of Arthur Talbot Johnstone, coachbuilder Mulliner’s managing director.

The name made a comeback on the back of a not-quite-so-elegant saloon version of the 2003 Continental GT coupé. Launched in 2005, that second Flying Spur belied its four doors, however; it had something of a reputation within Bentley’s engineering circles as better than the coupé to drive.

Buyers didn’t...
description: It sounds as exciting as soup;
